Alex C. Williams

Assistant Professor, EECS
University of Tennessee, Knoxville

I'm an Assistant Professor in the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville where I lead the Laboratory for Transformative Workplaces. My research intersects human-computer interaction, artificial intelligence, machine learning, cognitive science, and workplace studies. I earned my PhD from the University of Waterloo where I worked with Edith Law and Edward Lank.

Before joining UTK, I spent several months working as a postdoctoral researcher with Gloria Mark in the the University of California, Irvine's Informatics Department. I have also been a member of several research teams across Microsoft Research, Mozilla Research, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, and the University of Oxford.

Research Positions Available!: I'm looking for several students to join my lab at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville. If you're interested in doing graduate or undergraduate research in HCI or applied AI, get in touch via email!

News

  • June 2020:
    I'm serving as a PC Member for the 2020 Symposium on the New Future of Work.
  • June 2020:
    I'm teaching COSC425: Introduction to Machine Learning for the Fall 2020 term.
  • May 2020:
    I'm serving as Workshops Co-Chair for CSCW2020.
  • May 2020:
    Our preliminary user study with FireFox Voice was accepted to CUI2020's Poster track.
  • March 2020:
    I demo'd voice-powered web browsing with Firefox Voice at the CUI@CHI2020 workshop.

H. Kaur, A.C. Williams, D. McDuff, M. Czerwinski, J. Teevan, S. Iqbal.
Proceedings of the 2020 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI '20').

A.C. Williams, G. Mark, K. Milland, E. Lank, and E. Law.
Proceedings of the 23rd ACM Conference on Computer Supported Cooperative Work & Social Computing (CSCW '19').

PDF

Mercury: Empowering Programmers' Mobile Work Practices with Microproductivity.

Research Focus

Curiosity, Citizen Science, and Virtual Agents
My current research focuses on the intersection of curiosity, citizen science, and virtual agents. The theme of my research centers around how curiosity can be leveraged and exploited to make learners (i.e. volunteers or crowd-workers) more excited and engaged with scientific crowdsourcing tasks.
Experimental Human-in-the-Loop Systems
My research centers around building systems that integrate human input as a computational units. Building hyrbid human-machine systems that perform complex tasks better than either human or machine could independently is non-trivial. This area of work is exploratory and open-ended.

Personal

In my free time, I play classical guitar. A few of my favorite musicians that draw inspiration from the classical guitar literature are Django Reinhardt, Plini, and Intervals.

When I lived in England, I became a Baron of the principality of Sealand.
